52.verse: For from now on there will be five in one household divided, three against two and two against three;

53.verse: father will be divided against son and son against father, mother against daughter and daughter against mother, mother-in-law against her daughter-in-law and daughter-in-law against mother-in-law.”

54.verse: He also said to the crowds, “When you see a cloud rising in the west, you say at once, ‘A rainstorm is coming,’ and so it happens.

55.verse: And when there is a south wind blowing, you say, ‘There will be hot weather,’ and it happens.

56.verse: Hypocrites! You know how to interpret the appearance of the earth and the sky. How is it that you do not know how to interpret this present time?

57.verse: “Why, indeed, do you not judge for yourselves what is right?

58.verse: So when you go with your opponent before the magistrate, make an effort to receive a settlement from him on the way; otherwise he will drag you off to the judge, and the judge will hand you over to the bailiff, and the bailiff will throw you into prison.

59.verse: I say to you, you will certainly not get out of there until you have paid the last penny.”

1.verse: At that very time there were some present who told him about the Galileans whose blood Pilate had mingled with their sacrifices.

2.verse: In response he said to them, “Do you think that these Galileans were worse sinners than all the other Galileans, because they suffered these things?

3.verse: No, I tell you; but unless you repent, you will all perish as they did.

4.verse: Or those eighteen on whom the tower in Siloam fell and killed them—do you think that they were worse offenders than all the others living in Jerusalem?

5.verse: No, I tell you; but unless you repent, you will all perish just as they did.”

6.verse: Then he told this parable: “A man had a fig tree planted in his vineyard, and he came looking for fruit on it and found none.

7.verse: And he said to the vineyard worker, ‘Look, for three years now, I have come looking for fruit on this fig tree, and I find none. Remove it. Why should it use up the soil?’

8.verse: And he answered, saying to him, ‘Sir, leave it alone this year also, until I dig around it and put on manure.

9.verse: Perhaps it will bear fruit next year; but if not, you may remove it.’”

10.verse: Now he was teaching in one of the synagogues on the Sabbath,

11.verse: and there was a woman there who had had a spirit of weakness for eighteen years. She was bent over and not able to straighten up at all.

12.verse: Seeing her, Jesus called out and said to her, “Woman you are released from your weakness.”

13.verse: He placed his hands on her, and immediately she was made erect again and began to praise God.

14.verse: Indignant because Jesus had healed on the Sabbath, the ruler of the synagogue said to the crowd, “There are six days in which work ought to be done. Come on those days and be healed, and not on the Sabbath day.”

15.verse: Then the Lord answered him, saying, “You hypocrites! Does not each of you on the Sabbath untie his ox or his donkey from the manger to lead it away and to water it?

16.verse: And ought not this woman, a daughter of Abraham whom Satan bound for eighteen years, be released from this bondage on the day of the Sabbath?”

17.verse: As he said these things, all his adversaries were put to shame, while all the people rejoiced at all the glorious things that were done by him.

18.verse: Then he said, “What is the kingdom of God like, and to what shall I compare it?

19.verse: It is like a mustard seed that a man took and threw into his garden. It grew and became a tree, and the birds of the sky made nests in its branches.”

20.verse: And again he said, “To what shall I compare the kingdom of God?

21.verse: It is like leaven that a woman took and hid in three measures of flour, until it was all leavened.”

22.verse: Then Jesus went through town after town and village after village, teaching as he made his way to Jerusalem.

23.verse: Someone said to him, “Lord, will those who are saved be few?” And he said to them,

24.verse: “Do your best to go in through the narrow door; for many, I tell you, will try to go in and not be able.

25.verse: “Once the owner of the house has risen and shut the door, and you are left standing outside, knocking at the door, saying, ‘Sir, open the door for us!’ then he will respond to you, ‘I do not know you or where you are from.’

26.verse: Then you will say, ‘We ate and drank in your presence, and you taught in our streets.’

27.verse: And he will speak, saying to you, ‘I do not know you or where you are from. Depart from me, all you workers of unrighteousness!’

28.verse: There will be weeping and gnashing of teeth there, when you see Abraham and Isaac, and Jacob, and all the prophets in the kingdom of God, but you yourselves cast outside.

29.verse: “Then they will come from east and west, and from north and south, and recline at table in the kingdom of God.

30.verse: But take note, some who are last will be first, and some are first who will be last.”

31.verse: In that very hour some Pharisees came, saying to him, “Leave and get away from here, for Herod wants to kill you.”

32.verse: And he said to them, “Go and tell that fox, ‘Behold, I am casting out demons and performing cures today and tomorrow, and the third day I complete my task.’

33.verse: Nevertheless I must continue on my way today and tomorrow and the next day; because it is not possible for a prophet to die outside of Jerusalem.”

34.verse: “O Jerusalem, Jerusalem, the city that kills the prophets and stones those who have been sent to it! How often I wanted to gather your children together as a hen gathers her brood under her wings, and you did not want it!

35.verse: Behold, your house is left to you desolate. And I tell you, you will not see me until you say, ‘Blessed is the one who comes in the name of the Lord!’”

1.verse: When Jesus went into the house of a certain ruler of the Pharisees on the Sabbath to eat bread and they were watching him closely,

2.verse: it happened that a certain man suffering from dropsy was right there in front of him.

3.verse: In response Jesus spoke to the lawyers and Pharisees, saying, “Is it lawful on the Sabbath to heal, or not?”

4.verse: But they remained silent. So he took hold of the man, healed him, and sent him away.

5.verse: And to them, he said, “Which of you, when his son or his ox has fallen into a well, does not immediately pull it up, even on the Sabbath day?”

6.verse: And they were not able to give an answer to this.

7.verse: He began speaking a parable to those who had been invited when he noticed how they were seeking out the places of honor. He said to them,

8.verse: “When you are invited by someone to a wedding feast, do not take a seat in a place of honor, lest someone more distinguished than you may have been invited by your host,

9.verse: and the one who invited both you and him will say to you, ‘Give your place to this person,’ and then with shame you will proceed to take the least important place.

10.verse: Rather, when you are invited, go and recline in the least important place so that when the one who invited you comes he may say to you, ‘Friend, move up higher!’ Then you will have glory in the presence of all who are reclining at table with you.

11.verse: For everyone who exalts himself will be humbled, and the one who humbles himself will be exalted.”

12.verse: Then he also said to the one who had invited him, “When you give a luncheon or a dinner do not invite your friends, or your brothers, or your relatives, or rich neighbors, in case they also invite you in return, and there would be a repayment to you.

13.verse: But when you give a feast, invite the poor, the crippled, the lame, the blind.

14.verse: Then you will be blessed, because they do not have a way to pay you back, for there will be a repayment for you at the resurrection of the righteous.”

15.verse: When one of those reclining at table with him heard him say these things, he said to him, “Blessed is the person who will eat bread in the kingdom of God!”

16.verse: But he said to him, “A man once gave a great banquet and invited many guests.

17.verse: And he sent his servant at the hour of the banquet to say to those who had been invited, ‘Come, for everything is now ready.’

18.verse: But one after another they all began to make excuses. The first said to him, ‘I bought a field, and I must go out to see it. I ask you, have me excused.’

19.verse: And another said, ‘I have bought five yoke of oxen, and I am going to try them out. I ask you, have me excused.’

20.verse: And another said, ‘I have married a wife, and because of this I am not able to come.’

21.verse: So the servant came and reported these things to his master. Then the master of the house was angry and said to his servant, ‘Go out quickly into the streets and alleys of the city, and bring in here the poor, the crippled, the blind, and the lame.’

22.verse: The slave said, ‘Sir, what you ordered has been done, and still there is room.’

23.verse: The master said to the servant, ‘Go out to the highways and hedgerows and urge people to come in, so that my house may be filled.

24.verse: For I say to you that none of those men who were invited will taste my banquet.’”

25.verse: Great crowds of people were traveling with him, and he turned and said to them,

26.verse: “If anyone comes to me and does not hate his own father and mother, and wife and children, and brothers and sisters, and even his own life, he cannot be my disciple.

27.verse: Whoever does not carry his own cross and come after me cannot be my disciple.

28.verse: “For which of you, wanting to build a tower, does not first sit down and calculate the cost, whether he has enough to bring it to completion;

29.verse: otherwise, when he has laid the foundation and is not able to complete the tower, all who see it will begin to ridicule him,

30.verse: saying, ‘This man began to build and was not able to complete.’

31.verse: Or what king, going out to encounter another king in war, will not sit down first and deliberate whether he is able with ten thousand troops to oppose the one coming against him with twenty thousand?

32.verse: And if not, while he is yet a great way off, he will send a delegation and ask for terms of peace.

33.verse: In the same way, therefore, everyone of you who does not renounce all his possessions cannot be my disciple.

34.verse: “Salt, then, is good; but if salt has become insipid, with what shall it be seasoned?

35.verse: Neither for soil or for the dung-heap is it of any use; they throw it away. The one who has ears to hear, let him hear.”

1.verse: Now all the tax collectors and the sinners used to come near him to listen to him.

2.verse: And the Pharisees and the scribes were grumbling, saying, “This fellow welcomes sinners and eats with them!”

3.verse: So he told them this parable.

4.verse: “Which man among you, who has a hundred sheep, should he lose one of them, would not leave the ninety-nine in the open pasture and go after the one that is lost until he finds it?

5.verse: And when he finds it, would he not place it on his shoulders, rejoicing?

6.verse: And when he returns to his house, would he not call together his friends and his neighbors, and say to them, ‘Rejoice with me, for I have found my sheep that was lost’?

7.verse: I tell you, in the same way there will be more joy in heaven over one sinner who repents than over ninety-nine righteous people who have no need of repentance.

8.verse: “Or what woman, who has ten silver coins, should she lose one coin, would not light a lamp, sweep the house, and search diligently until she finds it?

9.verse: And when she finds it, would she not call together her friends and neighbors, saying, ‘Rejoice with me, for I have found the coin that I had lost’?

10.verse: Just so, I tell you, there is joy before the angels of God over one sinner who repents.”

11.verse: Then he said, “A certain man had two sons.

12.verse: The younger of them said to the father, ‘Father, give me the share of the property that will belong to me.’ So he divided the estate between them.

13.verse: Not many days later, the younger son gathered up everything and left for a journey to a distant country, and there he squandered his property by living recklessly.

14.verse: When he had spent everything, there was a severe famine in that country, and he began to be in need.

15.verse: So he went and hired himself out to one of the citizens of that country, and he sent him into his fields to feed pigs.

16.verse: He longed to be fed with the pods that the pigs were eating, but no one would give him anything.

17.verse: “Coming to himself, he said, ‘How many of my father’s hired servants have more than enough bread, but here I am, dying from hunger!

18.verse: I will leave this place and go to my father, and I will say to him, ‘Father, I have sinned against heaven and before you;

19.verse: I am no longer worthy to be called your son. Take me on as one of your hired servants.’

20.verse: So he left that place and went to his father. While he was still a long way from home, his father saw him and was filled with compassion; he ran and fell upon his neck and kissed him.

21.verse: And the son said to him, ‘Father, I have sinned against heaven and before you. I am no longer worthy to be called your son.’

22.verse: But the father said to his servants, ‘Quickly bring out a robe—the best one—and put it on him, and give him a ring for his finger, and sandals for his feet.

23.verse: Bring the fattened calf and make the kill! Let us eat and celebrate;

24.verse: for this, my son, was dead, and has come back to life again; he was lost, and has been found.’ So they began to celebrate.

25.verse: “Meanwhile his older son was in the field, and as he came and drew near to the house, he heard music and dancing.

26.verse: So calling one of his servants, he asked what this might be.

27.verse: The servant said to him, ‘Your brother has come, and your father has killed the fattened calf, because he received him back safe and sound.’

28.verse: But the older son became angry and refused to go in. His father came out and began to appeal to him,

29.verse: but he answered his father, ‘Look, these many years I have served you, and I never disregarded a command of yours, yet you never gave me a young goat, that I might celebrate with my friends.

30.verse: But when this son of yours came, who has consumed your estate with prostitutes, you killed the fattened calf for him!’

31.verse: Then the father said to him, ‘Son, you are always with me, and everything I have is yours.

32.verse: We had to celebrate and rejoice, because this brother of yours, was dead and has come alive; he was lost and has been found.’”

1.verse: Then Jesus also said to his disciples, “There was a rich man who had a manager, and charges were brought to him that this man was wasting his assets.

2.verse: So he called him in and said to him, ‘What is this I hear about you? Hand over the account of your stewardship, because you cannot be my manager any longer.’

3.verse: And the manager said to himself, ‘What shall I do, since my master is taking the management away from me? I am not strong enough to dig, and I am ashamed to beg.

4.verse: I know what to do, so that when I am removed from management, people will welcome me into their homes.’

5.verse: Calling each one of his master’s debtors, he said to the first, ‘How much do you owe my master?’

6.verse: He said, ‘A hundred measures of oil.’ So he told him, ‘Take your contract, sit down quickly, and write fifty.’

7.verse: Then he said to another, ‘And how much do you owe?’ He answered, ‘A hundred measures of wheat.’ He said to him, ‘Take your contract, and write eighty.’

8.verse: The master commended the dishonest manager because he acted shrewdly. For the sons of this world are more shrewd in dealing with their own generation than the sons of light.

9.verse: And I say to you, make friends for yourselves by means of the wealth of unrighteousness, so that when it fails they may receive you into the eternal homes.

10.verse: “The one who is faithful in the smallest thing is also faithful in something great; and the one who is dishonest in the smallest thing is also dishonest in something great.

11.verse: Therefore if in unrighteous wealth you have not been faithful, who will entrust to you that which is of true value?

12.verse: And if you have not been faithful in what belongs to another, who will give you what is to be your own?

13.verse: “No servant is able to serve two masters. For either he will hate the one and love the other, or he will be devoted to the one and despise the other. You cannot serve God and money.”

14.verse: The Pharisees (who were lovers of money) heard all these things, and they ridiculed him.

15.verse: And he said to them, “You are those who justify yourselves before men, but God knows your hearts. For what is exalted among men is an abomination before God.

16.verse: “The Law and the Prophets were until John; since then the good news of the kingdom of God is preached, and everyone takes vigorous steps to enter it.

17.verse: It is easier for heaven and earth to pass away than for the smallest part of a single letter in the law to lose its force.

18.verse: Anyone who divorces his wife and marries another woman commits adultery, and the one who marries a woman divorced from her husband commits adultery.

19.verse: A certain man was rich, and he was dressed in purple and fine linen and he made merry every day in a luxurious manner.

20.verse: And a poor man by the name of Lazarus, who was covered with sores, was laid at the gate,

21.verse: who longed to eat what fell from the rich man’s table. But instead, the dogs used to come and lick his sores.

22.verse: The poor man died and he was carried by the angels to Abraham’s side. The rich man also died and was buried,

23.verse: And being in torment in Hades, he lifted his eyes and saw Abraham from afar and Lazarus at his side.

24.verse: And calling out he said, ‘Father Abraham, have mercy on me, and send Lazarus to dip the tip of his finger in water and cool my tongue, for I am in anguish in this flame.’

25.verse: But Abraham said, ‘Child, remember that you received your good things during your lifetime, and Lazarus correspondingly received bad things; but now he is comforted here, and you are in anguish.

26.verse: Besides all this, between us and you a great chasm has been put in place, so that those wishing to cross over from here to you are not able, and no one can cross from there to us.’

27.verse: So the rich man said, ‘Then I beg you, father, to send Lazarus to the house of my father

28.verse: (for I have five brothers), that he might warn them so that they might not come as well into this place of torment.’

29.verse: But Abraham said, ‘They have Moses and the Prophets; let them listen to them.’

30.verse: Then the rich man said, ‘No, father Abraham; but if someone from the dead goes to them, they will repent.’

31.verse: He said to him, ‘If they do not listen to Moses and the Prophets, neither will they be persuaded should someone rise from the dead.’”

1.verse: And he said to his disciples, “It is inevitable that occasions for stumbling will come, but woe to the one through whom they come!

2.verse: It is better for him if a millstone is hung around his neck and he is cast into the sea than that he should cause one of these little ones to stumble.

3.verse: “Be on your guard! If your brother sins, rebuke him, and if he repents, forgive him.

4.verse: And if he sins against you seven times in a day, and seven times returns to you saying, ‘I repent,’ you must forgive him.”

5.verse: The apostles said to the Lord, “Increase our faith!”

6.verse: And the Lord said, “If you had faith like a grain of mustard seed, you could say to this sycamore, ‘Be uprooted and planted in the sea,’ and it would obey you.

7.verse: Which one of you, having a servant plowing or tending sheep, who, when he comes in from the field, will say to him, ‘Come here at once and recline at dinner’?

8.verse: Will he not, rather, say to him, ‘Prepare what I am to eat, then change clothes and wait on me while I eat and drink, and after this you may eat and drink’?

9.verse: Does he express thanks to the servant because he did the things that were commanded?

10.verse: So it is with you. When you have done all that was commanded, say, ‘We are unworthy servants; we have done no more than we were obliged to do.’”

11.verse: As Jesus was on his way to Jerusalem, he passed through the region between Samaria and Galilee.

12.verse: As he entered a certain village, ten men with leprosy met him, who normally stood at a distance.

13.verse: They raised their voices, saying, “Jesus, Master, have mercy on us!”

14.verse: When he saw them, he said to them, “Go and show yourselves to the priests.” And as they went they were made clean.

15.verse: Then one of them, when he saw that he had been healed, returned, praising God in a loud voice,

16.verse: and fell on his face at Jesus’ feet, giving him thanks—and he was a Samaritan.

17.verse: Then Jesus responded, saying, “Were not ten made clean? The other nine, where are they?

18.verse: Were they not found, so as to return and give praise to God, except this foreigner?”

19.verse: Then he said to the man, “Get up and go; your faith has made you well.”

20.verse: Having been asked by the Pharisees when the kingdom of God would come, he answered them, saying, “The kingdom of God will not come with observation.

21.verse: Nor will they say, ‘Look, here it is!’ or, ‘There it is!’ For behold, the kingdom of God is in the midst of you.”

22.verse: And he said to the disciples, “Days are coming when you will desire to see one of the days of the Son of Man, and you will not see it.

23.verse: And they will say to you, ‘Look, there!’ or, ‘Look, here!’ Do not go out or pursue them.

24.verse: For just as the lightning, when it flashes, lights up from one end of heaven to the other, so will be the Son of Man in his day.

25.verse: But first he must suffer many things and be rejected by this generation.

26.verse: And just as it was in the days of Noah, so also will it be in the days of the Son of Man.

27.verse: They were eating, they were drinking, they were marrying, they were being given in marriage, until the day in which Noah went into the ark and the flood came and destroyed them all.

28.verse: Likewise, just as it was in the days of Lot: they were eating, they were drinking, they were buying, they were selling, they were planting, they were building;

29.verse: but on the day in which Lot went out of Sodom, fire and sulfur rained down from heaven and destroyed them all.

30.verse: It will be just like this on the day the Son of Man is revealed.

31.verse: “On that day the one who is on the housetop, and his belongings are in the house, must not go down to get them, and likewise the one who is in the field must not turn back.

32.verse: Remember Lot’s wife.

33.verse: Whoever tries to retain his life for himself will lose it, and whoever loses his life will preserve it.

34.verse: I tell you, on that night there will be two in one bed; one will be taken and the other left behind.

35.verse: There will be two women grinding at the mill together; one will be taken and the other left behind.”

36.verse: verse doesn't exist in this bible version

37.verse: Then the disciples said to him in response, “Where, Lord?” And he said to them, “Where the corpse is, there also the vultures will be gathered.”

1.verse: Then Jesus told them a parable to the effect that they should continue to pray at all times and never give up.

2.verse: He said, “There was a certain judge in a certain city who neither feared God nor had any regard for people.

3.verse: There was a widow in that city, and she kept coming to him, saying, ‘Vindicate me against my adversary.’

4.verse: He didn’t want to for a time. But later on he said to himself, ‘Though I neither fear God nor have regard for people,

5.verse: yet because this widow keeps bothering me, I will vindicate her, so that by her coming she will not ultimately wear me out.’”

6.verse: And the Lord said, “Hear what the unrighteous judge says.

7.verse: Will not God certainly vindicate his elect, who cry to him day and night, and have patience with them?

8.verse: I tell you, he will vindicate them without delay; but will the Son of Man, when he comes, find faith on earth?”

9.verse: He also told this parable to some who were confident in themselves, because they were righteous, and treated others with contempt.

10.verse: “Two men went up into the temple to pray, the one a Pharisee and the other a tax collector.

11.verse: The Pharisee stood and prayed like this to himself: ‘God, I thank you that I am not like the rest of mankind—swindlers, rogues, adulterers, or even like this tax collector.

12.verse: I fast twice a week; I tithe all that I get.’

13.verse: The tax collector, however, standing at a distance, would not even raise his eyes to heaven, but kept beating his breast, saying, ‘God, be merciful to me, a sinner!’

14.verse: I tell you, this man went down to his house upright in the sight of God, rather than the other. For everyone who exalts himself will be humbled, and the one who humbles himself will be exalted.”

15.verse: Now people were bringing to him even little ones so he would touch them. However, when the disciples saw it, they began to rebuke them.

16.verse: But Jesus called them to him, saying, “Let the children come to me, and do not stop them, for it is to such as these that the kingdom of God belongs.

17.verse: I tell you the truth, whoever does not receive the kingdom of God like a child shall certainly never enter it.”

18.verse: Now a certain ruler asked him, saying, “Good Teacher, what must I do to inherit eternal life?”

19.verse: And Jesus said to him, “Why do you call me good? No one is good except one—God.

20.verse: You know the commandments: ‘You shall not commit adultery; You shall not murder; You shall not steal; You shall not bear false witness; Honor your father and mother.’

21.verse: The man replied, “All these I have kept since my youth.”

22.verse: Upon hearing this, Jesus said to him, “One thing you still lack: sell all that you have and distribute the proceeds to the poor, and you will have treasure in heaven. Then come, follow me.”

23.verse: But when he heard this, he became very sad, for he was extremely wealthy.

24.verse: Jesus looked at him, becoming very sad, and said, “How difficult it is for those who have wealth to enter the kingdom of God!

25.verse: In fact, it is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich man to enter the kingdom of God!”

26.verse: Those who heard it said, “Who, then, can be saved?”

27.verse: Jesus said, “What is impossible for mortal beings is possible for God.”

28.verse: Then Peter said, “Look, we have left what was ours and followed you.”

29.verse: Then Jesus said to them, “I tell you the truth, there is no one who has left home or wife or siblings or parents or children, for the sake of the kingdom of God

30.verse: who will not receive many times as much in this age and, in the age to come, eternal life.”

31.verse: Taking the twelve aside, he said to them, “See, we are going up to Jerusalem, and everything written by the prophets regarding the Son of Man will be carried out.

32.verse: For he will be handed over to the Gentiles and will be ridiculed and ill-treated and spat on.

33.verse: Then after scourging him, they will kill him, but on the third day he will arise again.”

34.verse: But the twelve understood none of these things; in fact, what he said was kept hidden from them and they did not grasp what was being said.

35.verse: As Jesus drew near to Jericho, there was a blind man sitting by the roadside, asking for alms.

36.verse: When he heard a crowd going by, he inquired what this might be.

37.verse: They told him that Jesus of Nazareth was passing by.

38.verse: So he called out, saying, “Jesus, Son of David, have mercy on me!”

39.verse: Those who were leading the way began to rebuke him that he should be quiet; but he cried out all the more, “Son of David, have mercy on me!”

40.verse: Jesus stopped and ordered the beggar to be brought to him. When the man had come near, Jesus asked him,

41.verse: “What do you want me to do for you?” He said, “Lord, that I might see again.”

42.verse: Jesus said to him, “See again! Your faith has saved you.”

43.verse: And immediately he could see again, and began to follow Jesus, giving glory to God. And all the people, when they saw this, gave praise to God.

1.verse: Jesus entered Jericho and was passing through.

2.verse: There was a man called by the name of Zacchaeus; he was a chief tax collector and he was wealthy.

3.verse: He was trying to see Jesus—who he was—but was not able to on account of the crowd, because he was short in stature.

4.verse: So he ran on ahead and climbed up into a sycamore-fig tree to see him, for he was about to pass that way.

5.verse: As he came to that spot, Jesus looked up and said to him, “Zacchaeus, hurry and climb down, for today I must stay at your house.”

6.verse: So he hurried and climbed down and welcomed him, rejoicing.

7.verse: And everyone, when they saw this, began to grumble, saying, “He went in to lodge with a sinful man.”

8.verse: Zacchaeus, as he stood there, said to the Lord, “Look, half of what I own, Lord, I will give to the poor, and if I have defrauded anyone of anything, I will repay fourfold.”

9.verse: Jesus said to him, “Today salvation has come to this house, since he too is a son of Abraham.

10.verse: For the Son of Man came to seek and to save the lost.”

11.verse: As they were listening to this, he went on to tell a parable, because he was near Jerusalem, and they supposed that the kingdom of God was going to appear at once.

12.verse: So he said, “A certain man of noble birth went to a distant country to acquire royal power for himself and then to return.

13.verse: So, calling ten of his servants, he gave them ten minas, and said to them, ‘Conduct business until I return.’

14.verse: But his citizens hated him and sent a delegation after him, saying, ‘We do not want this person to rule over us.’

15.verse: When he returned, having acquired royal power, he ordered these servants to whom he had given the money to be called to him, that he might know what they had gained by doing business.

16.verse: The first came before him, saying, ‘Master, your mina has gained ten minas.’

17.verse: And he said to him, ‘Well done, good servant! Because you have been trustworthy in a very small matter, you will have authority over ten cities.’

18.verse: And the second came, saying, ‘Your mina, Master, has gained five minas.’

19.verse: So he said to this one as well, ‘And you, rule over five cities.’

20.verse: Then the other came, saying, ‘Master, look, your mina that I kept laid away in a piece of cloth,

21.verse: for I was afraid of you, because you are an exacting man: you take up what you did not lay down, and reap what you did not sow.’

22.verse: He said to him, ‘Out of your own mouth I will judge you, wicked servant. You knew, did you, that I am an exacting man, taking up what I did not lay down and reaping what I did not sow?

23.verse: Why then did you not put my money in the bank? Then when I returned I could have collected it with interest.’

24.verse: Then he said to his attendants, ‘Take from him the mina and give it to the one who has the ten minas.’

25.verse: And they said to him, ‘Master, he has ten minas!’

26.verse: I tell you that to everyone who has, more will be given; but from the one who does not have, even what he has will be taken away.

27.verse: But as for these enemies of mine who did not want me to reign over them, bring them here and slaughter them before me.”

28.verse: Having said these things, he went on ahead, going up to Jerusalem.

29.verse: It happened that as he came near Bethphage and Bethany to the hill called “The Mount of Olives,” he sent two of his disciples,

30.verse: saying, “Go into the village ahead of you, where, as you enter, you will find a colt tied, on which no one has ever yet sat. Untie it and bring it here.

31.verse: If someone asks you why are you untying it, you shall say this: ‘The Lord has need of it.’”

32.verse: Those who were sent away left and found everything just as he has described it to them.

33.verse: As they were untying the colt, its owners said to them, “Why are you untying the colt?”

34.verse: And they said, “Because the Lord has need of it.”

35.verse: Then they brought it to Jesus, and throwing their cloaks onto the colt, they put Jesus on it.

36.verse: And as he rode along, they spread their cloaks on the road.

37.verse: As he was already approaching to the descent of the Mount of Olives, the whole crowd of disciples began to rejoice and praise God with a loud voice for all the mighty works that they had seen,

38.verse: saying, “Blessed is the coming one, the king, the one who comes in the name of the Lord! Peace in heaven and glory in the highest!”

39.verse: And some of the Pharisees in the crowd said to him, “Teacher, rebuke your disciples.”

40.verse: He answered, “I tell you, if these are silent, the stones will cry out.”

41.verse: As Jesus drew near and saw the city, he wept over it,

42.verse: saying, “Would that you, even you, had known on this day the things that make for peace! But now they are hidden from your eyes.

43.verse: For the days will come upon you when your enemies will build an embankment against you and surround you and close in on you from every side.

44.verse: And they will tear down both you and your children within you, and they will not leave stone upon stone in you, because you did not recognize the time of your visitation.”

45.verse: Having entered the temple, Jesus began to drive out those who were selling things,

46.verse: saying to them, “It is written, ‘My house shall be a house of prayer,’ but you have made it a den of robbers.”

47.verse: He began to teach daily in the temple. The chief priests and the scribes and the leading men among the people were trying to destroy him,

48.verse: but they could not find what they might do, because all the people were hanging on his words.

1.verse: One day, as Jesus was teaching the people in the temple and preaching the gospel, the chief priests and the scribes, along with the elders, came up

2.verse: and spoke to him, saying, “Tell us by what authority you are doing these things; or who it is who gave you this authority?”

3.verse: He answered, saying to them, “I will also ask you a question, and you must give me the answer:

4.verse: The baptism of John, was it authorized from heaven or did it come from men?”

5.verse: They reasoned among themselves, saying, “If we say, ‘From heaven,’ then he will say, ‘Why did you not believe him?’

6.verse: But if we say, ‘From men,’ all the people will stone us to death, because they are convinced that John was a prophet.”

7.verse: So they replied that they did not know where it was from.

8.verse: Then Jesus said to them, “Neither will I tell you by what authority I do these things.”

9.verse: Then he began to tell the people this parable: “A man planted a vineyard and leased it to tenants; then he went away for quite some time.

10.verse: When the season came, he sent a servant to the tenants so that they might give him his share of the produce of the vineyard; but the tenants beat him and sent him away empty-handed.

11.verse: So he sent another servant; but they beat that one as well, treated him shamefully, and sent him away empty-handed.

12.verse: So he sent a third; but they wounded this one too, and threw him out.

13.verse: Then the owner of the vineyard said, ‘What shall I do? I will send my son, whom I love; perhaps they will respect him.’

14.verse: When the tenants saw him, they reasoned among themselves, saying, ‘This is the heir. Let us kill him, so that the inheritance may be ours.’

15.verse: And they threw him out of the vineyard and killed him. What then will the owner of the vineyard do to them?

16.verse: He will come and destroy those tenants and give the vineyard to others.” When they heard this, they said, “Surely not!”

17.verse: But looking straight at them he said, “What then is this that is written: “The stone that the builders rejected—this one became the head of the corner’?

18.verse: Everyone who falls on that stone will be broken into pieces, and on whomever it falls, it will crush him.”

19.verse: The scribes and the chief priests tried to lay hands on him at that very hour, for they perceived that he had spoken this parable against them, but they feared the people.

20.verse: So they watched him closely and sent spies who pretended to be righteous so they could catch him in his word, and in this way deliver him to the jurisdiction and authority of the governor.

21.verse: They questioned him, saying, “Teacher, we know that you speak and teach truthfully and show no partiality, but truly teach the way of God.

22.verse: Is it lawful for us to give tribute to Caesar, or not?”

23.verse: But he realized their duplicity, and said to them,

24.verse: “Show me a denarius. Whose image and inscription does it have?” They said, “Caesar’s.”

25.verse: He said to them, “Then give to Caesar the things that are Caesar’s, and to God the things that are God’s.”

26.verse: And they were unable to trap him in what he said in the presence of the people, but, marveling at his answer, they were reduced to silence.

27.verse: Now some Sadducees (who deny there is a resurrection) came up and questioned him,

28.verse: saying, “Teacher, Moses wrote for us that if someone’s brother dies, having a wife, but is childless, then his brother must take the widow and raise up offspring for his brother.

29.verse: Now there were seven brothers. The first, having taken a wife, died childless.

30.verse: Both the second

31.verse: and the third took her, and likewise also the seven: they left no children and died.

32.verse: Later on the woman also died.

33.verse: So the woman—in the resurrection—of which of them will she be wife? For all seven had her as wife.”

34.verse: And Jesus said to them, “The sons of this age marry and are given in marriage,

35.verse: but those who are considered worthy to attain to that age and to the resurrection from the dead neither marry nor are given in marriage.

36.verse: In fact, they can no longer die, since they are like angels and are sons of God, being sons of the resurrection.

37.verse: But that the dead are raised, even Moses made known, in the passage about the bush, for he calls the Lord, ‘the God of Abraham and the God of Isaac and the God of Jacob.’

38.verse: He is not God of the dead, but of the living! For to him they are all alive.”

39.verse: In response some of the scribes said, “Teacher, you have spoken well!”

40.verse: For no longer did they dare to question him about anything.

41.verse: Then he said to them, “How can they say that the Messiah is to be a son of David?

42.verse: For David himself says in the book of Psalms, ‘The Lord said to my Lord, “Sit at my right hand,

43.verse: until I make your enemies a footstool for your feet.”’

44.verse: David thus calls him ‘Lord.’ So how could he be his son?”

45.verse: As all the people were listening, he said to his disciples,

46.verse: “Beware of those scribes, who like to walk around in flowing robes, and love greetings in the marketplaces and the most important seats in the synagogues and the places of honor at feasts,

47.verse: who devour the houses of widows and for the sake of appearance make lengthy prayers. These will receive the greater condemnation.”

1.verse: Looking up, Jesus saw rich people putting their gifts into the offering box,

2.verse: and he saw a poor widow put in two small coins.

3.verse: And he said, “I tell you the truth, that this poor widow has put in more than all the rest.

4.verse: For they all, out of their excess, put in their gifts, but she, out of her need, put in everything that she had to live on.”

5.verse: And while some were speaking of the temple, how it was adorned with beautiful stones and gifts dedicated to God, Jesus said,

6.verse: “These things that you see—days will come in which there will not be left stone upon stone that will not be thrown down.”

7.verse: And they asked him, saying, “Teacher, when will these things be, and what is the sign when these things are about to happen?”

8.verse: And he said, “See that you are not led astray! For many will come in my name, saying, ‘I am he!’ and, ‘The time is at hand!’ Do not go after them.

9.verse: When you hear of wars and rebellions, do not be terrified, for these things must take place first, but the end will not follow immediately.”

10.verse: Then he said to them, “Nation will rise against nation, and kingdom against kingdom;

11.verse: there will be great earthquakes, and in various places famines and plagues. There will be dreadful portents and great signs from heaven.

12.verse: But before all these things, they will lay their hands on you and persecute you, handing you over to the synagogues and prisons, bringing you before kings and governors for the sake of my name.

13.verse: This will result in an opportunity for you for witness.

14.verse: So determine in your hearts not to rehearse beforehand how to defend yourself,

15.verse: For I am the one who will give you a mouth and wisdom, which none of your adversaries will be able to resist or contradict.

16.verse: You will be handed over even by parents and brothers and relatives and friends, and some of you they will put to death.

17.verse: You will be hated by all because of my name.

18.verse: Yet not a hair of your head will perish.

19.verse: By your endurance you will gain your lives.

20.verse: “But when you see Jerusalem surrounded by armies, then know that its desolation has drawn near.

21.verse: Then those who are in Judea must flee to the mountains, and those in the midst of the city must evacuate, and those in the country must not enter it,

22.verse: for these are days of vengeance, so that everything that has been written may be fulfilled.

23.verse: Woe to those who are pregnant and to those who are nursing infants in those days! For there will be great distress on the earth and wrath against this people.

24.verse: They will fall by the edge of the sword and be led captive to all nations, and Jerusalem will be trampled underfoot by the Gentiles, until the times of the Gentiles are fulfilled.

25.verse: “There will be signs in the sun and moon and stars; and on the earth distress among nations confused by the roaring and surging of the sea;

26.verse: people fainting with fear and foreboding of what is coming on the world. For the powers of the heavens will be shaken.

27.verse: And then they will see the Son of Man coming on a cloud with power and great glory.

28.verse: Now when these things begin to happen, straighten yourselves up and raise your heads, because your deliverance is drawing near.”

29.verse: And he told them a parable: “Look at the fig tree, and all the trees.

30.verse: When they have already put forth their leaves, you see for yourselves and know that summer is already near.

31.verse: So also you, when you see these things happening, will know that the kingdom of God is near.

32.verse: I tell you the truth, that this generation will by no means have passed away before all things have happened.

33.verse: Heaven and earth will pass away, but my words will not pass away.

34.verse: “But watch yourselves lest your minds be dulled by dissipation and drunkenness and the anxieties of this life, and that day close down upon you suddenly,

35.verse: like a trap. For it will come upon all those who live on the face of the whole earth.

36.verse: Be alert at all times, praying that you may have strength to escape all these things that will take place, and to stand before the Son of Man.”

37.verse: During the day he was in the temple teaching, but at night he went out and stayed on the hill called “The Mount of Olives.”

38.verse: And all the people came to him in the temple at dawn to listen to him.

1.verse: Now the Festival of Unleavened Bread, which is called the Passover, was drawing near.

2.verse: The chief priests and the scribes were looking for a way how they might put Jesus to death, for they were afraid of the people.

3.verse: Then Satan entered into Judas, the one called Iscariot, who was of the number of the twelve.

4.verse: He went and conferred with the chief priests and officers about how he might deliver up Jesus to them.

5.verse: They were delighted and decided to give him money.

6.verse: He agreed and began looking for an opportunity to deliver him up to them in the absence of a crowd.

7.verse: Then came the day of Unleavened Bread, in which the Passover lamb had to be sacrificed.

8.verse: So Jesus sent Peter and John, saying, “Go and prepare the Passover for us, that we may eat it together.”

9.verse: They said to him, “Where do you want us to prepare it?”

10.verse: He said to them, “Look, when you have entered the city, a man carrying a jar of water will meet you. Follow him into the house into which he enters

11.verse: and say to the master of the house, ‘The Teacher says to you, “Where is the guest room, where I may eat the Passover with my disciples?”’

12.verse: He will show you a large room upstairs, already furnished. Make preparations for us there.”

13.verse: So they went and found everything as he had said to them; and they prepared the Passover meal.

14.verse: And when the hour came, Jesus reclined at table and the apostles were with him.

15.verse: He said to them, “With great desire I desired to eat this Passover with you before I suffer!

16.verse: For I say to you that I will certainly not eat it again until it is fulfilled in the kingdom of God.”

17.verse: Then he took a cup, and after he had given thanks he said, “Take this and divide it among yourselves.

18.verse: For I say to you that from now on I shall certainly not drink of the fruit of the vine until the kingdom of God comes.”

19.verse: Then taking bread and giving thanks he broke it and gave it to them, saying, “This is my body, which is given for you; do this in remembrance of me.”

20.verse: And he did the same with the cup after they had eaten, saying, “This cup is the new covenant in my blood, which on your behalf is being poured out.

21.verse: “But see, the hand of the one who will betray me is with me on the table.

22.verse: For the Son of Man goes according to what has been determined, but woe to that man by whom he is betrayed.”

23.verse: And they began to question among one another, which of them it might be who would do this.

24.verse: A dispute also arose among them as to which of them seemed to be the greatest.

25.verse: So Jesus said to them, “The kings of the nations exercise lordship over them and those in authority over them call themselves ‘benefactors.’

26.verse: But with you it must not be so! Rather, let the greatest among you become like the youngest, and the leader like the one who serves.

27.verse: For who is the greater, the one who reclines at table or the one who serves? Is it not the one who reclines at table? But in your midst I am like the one who serves.

28.verse: You are the ones who have stayed with me in my trials.

29.verse: Just as my Father conferred on me kingly authority, so also do I confer it on you,

30.verse: that you may eat and drink at my table in my kingdom and sit on thrones judging the twelve tribes of Israel.

31.verse: Simon, Simon! Pay attention! Satan has demanded permission to have all of you for himself, to sift you like wheat,

32.verse: but I have prayed for you that your faith may not fail. And when you have returned, strengthen your brothers.”

33.verse: Peter said to him, “Lord, I am ready to go with you both to prison and to death.”

34.verse: Jesus said, “I tell you, Peter, a rooster will not crow this day before you have denied three times that you know me.”

35.verse: And he said to them, “When I sent you out without moneybag or knapsack or sandals, did you lack anything?” They replied, “Nothing.”

36.verse: He said to them, “But now let the one who has a moneybag take it, and likewise a knapsack. And the one who has no sword, let him sell his cloak and buy one.

37.verse: For I tell you that there must be fulfilled in me this that stands written: ‘And he was numbered with the lawless.’ And indeed, that which concerns me has its fulfillment.”

38.verse: So they said, “Lord, look! Here are two swords.” Then he told them, “It is enough.”

39.verse: Then Jesus went out and made his way, as was his custom, to the Mount of Olives; and the disciples followed him.

40.verse: When he arrived at the place, he said to them, “Pray that you may not enter a time of trial.”

41.verse: Then he withdrew from them about a stone’s throw, knelt down and began to pray,

42.verse: saying, “Father, if you are willing, take this cup away from me. Yet, not my will, but yours be done.”

43.verse: And there appeared to him an angel from heaven, strengthening him.

44.verse: And being in agony he prayed more earnestly; and his sweat became like great drops of blood falling down to the ground.

45.verse: When he rose from prayer, he went back to the disciples and found them sleeping from grief.

46.verse: He said to them, “Why are you sleeping? Rise and pray that you may not enter a time of trial.”

47.verse: While he was still speaking, there came a crowd, and the one called Judas, one of the twelve, was coming on ahead of them. He went up to Jesus to kiss him,

48.verse: but Jesus said to him, “Judas, is it with a kiss that you intend to betray the Son of Man?”

49.verse: When those who were around him saw what was about to happen, they said, “Lord, shall we strike with the sword?”

50.verse: And a certain one of them struck the servant of the high priest and cut off his right ear.

51.verse: In response Jesus said, “Stop! No more of this.” And touching the ear, he healed it.

52.verse: Then Jesus said to those who had come out against him—the chief priests and officers of the temple and elders, “Why did you come out as against a robber, with swords and clubs?

53.verse: Day after day, when I was with you in the temple, you did not stretch out your hands against me. But this is your hour, and the hour for the power of darkness.

54.verse: Then they seized him and led him away, and brought him into the house of the high priest. Peter was following at a distance.

55.verse: Some people had kindled a fire in the middle of the courtyard and sat down together. Peter sat down among them.

56.verse: Seeing him sitting at the fire, a certain servant girl looked at him intently and said, “This man also was with him.”

57.verse: But he denied it, saying, “Woman, I do not know him!”

58.verse: After a little while someone else noticed him and said, “You also are one of them.” But Peter said, “Man, I am not!”

59.verse: Then after about an hour had passed a certain other person kept insisting, saying, “Surely this person also was with him, for he too is a Galilean.”

60.verse: But Peter said, “Man, I do not know what you are talking about.” And immediately, while he was still speaking, the rooster crowed.

61.verse: Then the Lord turned and looked at Peter, and Peter remembered the word of the Lord that he had said to him, “Before the rooster crows today, you will deny me three times.”

62.verse: And he went out and wept bitterly.

63.verse: Now the men who were holding Jesus in custody began to mock him and beat him,

64.verse: and blindfolding him they kept asking, “Tell us, who is it that struck you?”

65.verse: They also said to him many other blasphemous things.

66.verse: And when day came, the council of elders of the people was assembled, both chief priests and scribes, and they had Jesus brought into their council chamber

67.verse: and said, “If you are the Messiah, tell us.” But he said to them, “If I tell you, you will not believe,

68.verse: and if I question you, you will not answer.

69.verse: But from now on the Son of Man shall be seated at the right hand of the power of God.”

70.verse: They all said, “Are you, then, the Son of God?” And he said to them, “You say that I am.”

71.verse: Then they said, “What further need do we have of a witness? For we have heard it ourselves from his own lips.”

1.verse: Then the whole assembly of them rose up and brought Jesus before Pilate.

2.verse: And they began to accuse him, saying, “We found this man trying to mislead our nation, opposing the payment of taxes to Caesar, and claiming himself to be Christ, a king.”

3.verse: So Pilate asked Jesus, saying, “Are you the king of the Jews?” In response Jesus said to him, “You say so.”

4.verse: Then Pilate said to the chief priests and the crowds, “I find no basis for a charge against this man.”

5.verse: But they kept insisting, saying, “He stirs up the people, teaching throughout all Judea, starting from Galilee even to this place.”

6.verse: Now when Pilate heard this, he asked whether the man was a Galilean.

7.verse: Learning that he was from Herod’s jurisdiction, he sent him off to Herod, who was also in Jerusalem during those days.

8.verse: Upon seeing Jesus, Herod was very glad, since for a long time he had been wanting to see him, because of what he had heard about him, and he was hoping to see some miraculous sign done by him.

9.verse: So Herod questioned him with many words; but Jesus gave him no answer,

10.verse: even though the chief priests and the scribes stood by, vehemently accusing him.

11.verse: Then, when Herod, along with his soldiers, had treated him with contempt and ridiculed him, they put an elegant robe on him, and sent him back to Pilate.

12.verse: And Herod and Pilate became friends with each other that very day, for before this they had been hostile toward each other.

13.verse: Pilate then called together the chief priests, the rulers, and the people,

14.verse: and said to them, “You brought me this man as one who was trying to mislead the people. And indeed, having examined him in your presence, I found no basis for your charges against this man.

15.verse: For that matter, neither did Herod, for he sent him back to us. Look, nothing deserving death has been done by him.

16.verse: So I will have him flogged and release him.”

17.verse: verse doesn't exist in this bible version

18.verse: But they cried out together, saying, “Take this man away! Release for us Barabbas!”

19.verse: who was thrown into prison because of a certain riot that had occurred in the city and for murder.

20.verse: Once again Pilate, wanting to release Jesus, called out to them,

21.verse: but they kept shouting, saying, “Crucify, crucify him!”

22.verse: A third time he spoke to them, “What evil did this man do? I have found in him no guilt deserving death. I will therefore punish and release him.”

23.verse: But they were insistent, demanding with loud cries that he should be crucified, and their cries prevailed.

24.verse: So Pilate decided that their demand should be granted.

25.verse: He released the man who had been thrown into prison for insurrection and murder, for whom they asked, but he handed over Jesus to their will.

26.verse: As they led him away, they took hold of a certain Simon of Cyrene, who was coming in from the countryside, and put the cross on him to carry it behind Jesus.

27.verse: And there followed him a great crowd of the people, and among them were women who were mourning and wailing for him.

28.verse: Turning to them, Jesus said, “Daughters of Jerusalem, do not weep for me, but weep for yourselves and for your children.

29.verse: For the days are surely coming when they will say, ‘Blessed are the barren and the wombs that never gave birth and the breasts that never nursed!’

30.verse: Then they will begin to say to the mountains, ‘Fall on us!’ and to the hills, ‘Cover us!’

31.verse: For if they do these things when the wood is green, what will happen when it is dry?”

32.verse: And they also led away two others, who were criminals, to be put to death with him.

33.verse: And when they came to the place called “The Skull,” there they crucified him and the criminals—one on his right and one on his left.

34.verse: And Jesus was saying, “Father, forgive them; for they do not know what they are doing.” Then in order to divide up his clothing they cast lots.

35.verse: The people stood by, watching. The rulers even scoffed at him, saying, “He saved others; let him save himself, if he is the Christ of God, the Chosen One!”

36.verse: The soldiers, also, mocked him, coming up and offering him sour wine

37.verse: and saying, “If you are the king of the Jews, save yourself!”

38.verse: In fact, there was an inscription above him, “This is the King of the Jews.”

39.verse: One of the criminals hanging there kept deriding him, saying, “Are you not the Messiah? Save yourself and us!”

40.verse: But the other responded to him with a rebuke, saying, “Do you not fear God, since you are under the same sentence?

41.verse: And we indeed justly. For we are receiving what we deserve for what we did; but this man has done nothing improper.”

42.verse: Then he said, “Jesus, remember me when you come in your kingdom.”

43.verse: And Jesus said to him, “In solemn truth I tell you: today you will be with me in paradise.”

44.verse: It was already only about the sixth hour but darkness covered the whole land until the ninth hour,

45.verse: because the light of the sun had been eclipsed. The curtain of the temple was torn down the middle.

46.verse: Then Jesus, crying out in a loud voice, said, “Father, into your hands I commit my spirit!” Having said this, he breathed his last.

47.verse: Now when the centurion saw what had happened, he praised God, saying, “Truly this man was righteous!”

48.verse: And when all the crowds who had gathered for this spectacle saw what had happened, they returned home, beating their breasts.

49.verse: And all who knew Jesus, including the women who had followed him from Galilee, were standing at a distance, watching these things.

50.verse: Now there was a man named Joseph, a member of the Council, a good and righteous man.

51.verse: (He had not agreed with their decision or their action.) He was from the Jewish town of Arimathea, and he was waiting expectantly for the kingdom of God.

52.verse: This man went to Pilate and asked for the body of Jesus;

53.verse: then taking it down, he wrapped it in a linen cloth, and laid him in a tomb cut in stone, where no one had yet been laid.

54.verse: It was the day of preparation and the Sabbath was about to begin.

55.verse: The women who had come with him from Galilee followed along behind and saw the tomb, and how his body was laid in it

56.verse: Then they returned and prepared anointing spices and perfumes. On the Sabbath they rested according to the commandment.

1.verse: But on the first day of the week, at early dawn, the women came to the tomb, bringing the anointing spices that they had prepared.

2.verse: They found the stone rolled away from the tomb,

3.verse: and going inside they did not find the body of the Lord Jesus.

4.verse: It happened that, while they were wondering about this, suddenly two men stood beside them dressed in dazzling attire.

5.verse: The women were frightened and bowed their faces to the ground, but the men said to them, “Why do you look for the living among the dead?

6.verse: He is not here, but he has been raised. Remember how he spoke to you, while he was still in Galilee,

7.verse: saying that it was necessary for the Son of Man to be delivered into the hands of sinful men and to be crucified and on the third day to rise again.”

8.verse: Then they remembered his words.

9.verse: And returning from the tomb, they told all these things to the eleven and to all the others.

10.verse: It was Mary Magdalene and Joanna and Mary the mother of James and the other women with them. They kept telling these things to the apostles,

11.verse: but these words seemed like nonsense to them, and they did not believe them.

12.verse: But Peter got up and ran to the tomb; and bending down he saw the strips of linen by themselves, and he went away wondering to himself what had happened.

13.verse: Now on that same day two of them were on their way to a village about seven miles from Jerusalem, Emmaus by name.

14.verse: And they were talking with one another about all these things that had taken place.

15.verse: While they were talking and debating these things, it happened that Jesus himself drew near and walked along with them,

16.verse: but their eyes were kept from recognizing him.

17.verse: He said to them, “What are these matters that you are discussing with each other as you walk along?” They came to a stop, looking sad.

18.verse: Then one of them, named Cleopas, answered, saying to him, “Are you the only visitor to Jerusalem who does not know the things that have happened there in these days?”

19.verse: And he said to them, “What things?” They answered him, “The things about Jesus of Nazareth, a man who was a prophet mighty in deed and word before God and all the people,

20.verse: that our chief priests and rulers delivered him up to be condemned to death and crucified him.

21.verse: But we had hoped that he was the one who was going to redeem Israel. Indeed, besides all this, but it is now the third day since these things happened.

22.verse: Moreover, some women of our group astonished us: going to the tomb early in the morning

23.verse: and not finding his body, they came back saying that they had even seen a vision of angels who said that he was alive.

24.verse: Then some of those who were with us went to the tomb, and found it just as the women had said, but him they did not see.”

25.verse: So he said to them, “You foolish people, slow of heart to believe in all that the prophets have spoken!

26.verse: Was it not necessary for the Messiah to suffer these things and enter into his glory?”

27.verse: Then, beginning with Moses and all the Prophets, he interpreted to them the things written about himself in all the Scriptures.

28.verse: When they drew near to the village to which they were going, he made as though he was going farther,

29.verse: but they urged him strongly, saying, “Stay with us, for it is toward evening and the day is already far spent.” So he went in to stay with them.

30.verse: When he was reclining at the table with them, he took the bread, blessed and broke it, and gave it to them.

31.verse: At this point their eyes were opened, and they recognized him. Then he vanished from their sight.

32.verse: They said to each other, “Were not our hearts burning within us as he spoke to us on the road, as he opened to us the Scriptures?”

33.verse: So they got up that very hour and returned to Jerusalem, where they found the eleven and those with them gathered together,

34.verse: saying, “The Lord has indeed been raised and has appeared to Simon!”

35.verse: Then the two explained what had happened on the road, and how Jesus had been made known to them in the breaking of the bread.

36.verse: While they were saying these things, Jesus himself stood in their midst and said to them, “Peace to you.”

37.verse: But they were startled and frightened, and thought they were seeing a ghost.

38.verse: And he said to them, “Why are you so troubled and why are doubts arising in your hearts?

39.verse: Look at my hands and my feet, that it is I myself. Touch me and see, for a ghost does not have flesh and bones as you see that I have.”

40.verse: When he had said this, he showed them his hands and his feet.

41.verse: While they still could not believe it for joy and were continuing to marvel, he said to them, “Have you anything to eat here?”

42.verse: They gave him a piece of broiled fish,

43.verse: and he took it and ate in their presence.

44.verse: Then he said to them, “These are my words which I spoke to you while I was still with you, that everything written in the law of Moses and the prophets and psalms about me must be fulfilled.”

45.verse: Then he opened their minds so they could understand the scriptures,

46.verse: and said to them, “Thus it is written, that the Messiah is to suffer and to rise from the dead on the third day,

47.verse: and that repentance and forgiveness of sins is to be proclaimed in his name to all the nations, beginning from Jerusalem.

48.verse: You are witnesses of these things.

49.verse: And behold, I am sending the promise of my Father upon you, but stay in the city until you have been clothed with power from on high.”

50.verse: Then he led them out as far as Bethany, and lifting up his hands he blessed them.

51.verse: While he was blessing them, he departed from them and was carried up into heaven.

52.verse: And they worshiped him and returned to Jerusalem with great joy,

53.verse: and they were continually in the temple blessing God.
